posts.cooked:
A common complaint of new users - especially former Telegram users - is that their previous chat history is not available on newly linked (desktop) devices. This should be resolved by transferring the chat history from the phone or other existing devices to the new device via the Internet. Could be implemented more or less by forwarding the messages via the Signal protocol with an additional “history tag” or so.

This process should preferrably:

  • by default only occur when all devices are in a WLAN, to save mobile internet traffic (configurable)
  • have the ability to be invoked at a later time, because it is likely a lengthy process, but users want to use the desktop app immediately
  • be able to be interrupted and continued - lengthy process, WLAN connection might be lost, etc
  • the case of unlinked and relinked devices must be handled. A naive full transfer would lead to duplicate messages.

I don’t know if currently each message has a unique id, but if that is the case, one could compare lists of ids and only transfer the missing messages.

It would also be useful to allow a transfer from the desktop to the phone. This way, the desktop would serve as a kind of automatic backup. If the phone is lost, the existing messages would be transferred from the desktop install to the new phone.

posts.cooked:
Hello!

I would strongly vote against such a feature.

Someone would just need to grab your phone for a short period (for example: you visit a party and go to toilet, and someone asks you for your phone to make a phone call) to start this syncing on a computer. Sure, later you could see in your Signal phone settings, that there is another device, and you can remove it.
But while now, he would maybe able to grab just a few messages, with such an additional feature,he could grab all messages you sent and got during the last years.

Someone, who uses Telegram Desktop is a person, who has absolutely no awareness for security. So, whatever these people desire, should not be important for Signal, I think.

Many people are not aware, that using Signal on a Desktop (for example, a Windows computer) is NOT as secure as using it on a phone. That is, why everyone should be a bit careful with the Desktop application.

Kathy

Don’t leave your unlocked phone alone in the hands of untrustworthy people! Seriously, I don’t think anyone who would get in danger if someone had his messages would be that stupid.

However, to be extra safe, one could require pin/password entry before allowing the sync. This would make your scenario impossible.

On the other hand, this feature would attract many new users and a wide adoption of Signal would be good.

xyzzyx:

Don’t leave your unlocked phone alone in the hands of untrustworthy people! Seriously, I don’t think anyone who would get in danger if someone had his messages would be that stupid.

Hello!

I would not do that, but I see people giving their phone away everywhere I am. And yes, on parties I have seen such a behaviour many times. Most people are simply not aware of all these threats. And of course normal users do not use a pin for Signal (actually on iPhone I should say Touch ID or Face ID).

It should not be the primary goal to attract more users. Signal needs the right users.

Kathy

Kathy, that sounds like a random edge case. I think you’ve got lot bigger problems when handing out your phone unlocked to untrusted people.

If you’re on iOS, look into “guided mode”. You can lock the screen to one app and hand over your phone like that. But mostly: don’t give your phone to random people or be there at all times.

For the feature:
Viber already does this first time desktop app install sync. I’d recommend people look into it, they did a really nice UX there.

Licapengh:

If you’re on iOS, look into “guided mode”. You can lock the screen to one app and hand over your phone like that. But mostly: don’t give your phone to random people or be there at all times.

On Android you can add a temporary Guest account. If you hand over your phone, your guest can use the phone but has no access to your data or apps.

kathy:

It should not be the primary goal to attract more users. Signal needs the right users.

Sounds like a perfectly legit development philosophy.

Licapengh:

Kathy, that sounds like a random edge case. I think you’ve got lot bigger problems when handing out your phone unlocked to untrusted people.

Hello!

I see that as a normal everyday threat.
People might also use Signal Desktop on different computers. Maybe on the computer at home, at the second computer at work, maybe another computer at your parents home…
Someone might also quickly install the Signal Desktop version on a computer somewhere, to write a longer message and to uninstall the application afterwards. What a disaster, if the entire history would be synced, especially since we know, that Signal might not delete things correctly.

When you start the desktop application from Wickr for the first time, you get this message:
“We like privacy too, so for privacy reasons your conversation history will not appear on this device, but all future conversations will.”

Good job by Wickr.

Kathy

kathy:

install the Signal Desktop version on a computer somewhere, to write a longer message and to uninstall the application afterwards. What a disaster, if the entire history would be synced,

In that case, the user would of course choose not to sync. There would be a pop-up dialog asking for permission.

kathy:

Someone would just need to grab your phone for a short period (for example: you visit a party and go to toilet, and someone asks you for your phone to make a phone call) to start this syncing on a computer.

This line of argument could be leveled against all sorts of features such as backups, the forwarding of messages, etc. Personally I don’t find it very convincing. Being able to hand your phone to someone you don’t trust (e.g. for them to search the web or make a phone call) is precisely what Signal’s lock screen is for.

kathy:

It should not be the primary goal to attract more users. Signal needs the right users.

Signal’s stated mission is to “make private communication simple” and accessible to everyone. If what you want is a project that caters to a small, “power user”-type demographic, Signal may not be what you’re looking for.

link_counts.title: Are we shifting from geeks only app for masses?

posts.cooked:
This feature would be fantastic, in reality web sync would make it even more accessible.

The “security concerns” brought up are all dependent on physical access, at which point it’s all over.

I wouldn’t take those use cases as reasons not to full sync.

Take WhatsApp for example, notifications that the web app is in use; mitagation and accessibility vs physical access loss.

I will be a big advocate for full sync on desktop app or a future web app.

+1

posts.cooked:
anon61161739:

Many people are not aware, that using Signal on a Desktop (for example, a Windows computer) is NOT as secure as using it on a phone. That is, why everyone should be a bit careful with the Desktop application.

The phone can be hacked on the cellular layer, and Signal data would be available before encrypting and after decrypting. A desktop doesn’t have that vulnerability, so I don’t fully understand that statement. I do think there is much more physical access to a computer because people don’t hold it and put it in their pocket; rather, they separate them-self from a computer much more.

As a new Signal user I am very disappointed of this lacking feature. As this situation occurs only a few times there isn’t a problem with constructing a secure, but lavish process. Basicly the only concern I got from skimming this thread is when getting your device in hands it does not belong. If there would be any security concerns with syncing in general that feature shouldn’t exist either. So, when having an algorithm that needs two confirmations within, say a day, an attack which involves a scenario like Kathy mentioned, would be much more difficult. For example you can opt-in synchronization in general, which needs a day, an then if activated, sync between devices with a short confirmation. Anyway I like having my conversations syncronized between my devices, so I would be pleased having such a feature.

posts.name: Günter
posts.cooked:
I would also vote for a desktop synch feature:

  • Not really a security Issue: If somebody gets a hand on your on locked phone he or she can read, copy, plaintext export, or at least make a photo of your messages, and besides all the other data on your phone. So I think this is not really an issue. And there are for sure workarounds: Two way confirm… if the email takes some time to be sent it won’t do to have your phone for only 5min and if somebody has it for longer your data are gone anyways.

  • Provides 2nd device “Backup”: The advantage is, that you have a backup of you signal messages - even if your phone is stolen (locked or not), all your messages would be gone. This way you have them at least on your computer.

  • Generally and simply: Very handy for writing and sending photos which are not stored on the smartphone (I’m too old to live only on my smartphone)

I also like this feature very well. I myself am a new signal user and I felt it bad to learn that my messages are not completely synchronized. Now I wait and hope the signal integrates this feature.
This feature is even mandatory for today. I just want to be able to see my messages on my smartphone, but also on my MacBook.

simeler:

I just want to be able to see my messages on my smartphone, but also on my MacBook.

After you install and setup the desktop client, it does synchronize with your phone all future Signal messages you send and receive. Just to be clear, is it the synchronization of past messages that you want, i.e. of messages that are older than your Signal-Desktop installation?

Yes exactly. Past messages are not synced with. That confused me a bit. If I want to search for a past message, I can not do that because it will not sync on the desktop version. And when it comes time to reinstall your MacBook, it’s all gone anyway. Except on the smartphone of course. I think that the way it is done now is not very practical. Maybe the signal will change in the future. I would wish it very much.

simeler:

And when it comes time to reinstall your MacBook, it’s all gone anyway.

You can backup your Signal-Desktop folder and restore it on your new installation.

accepted_answer.name: Talya (she/her)
accepted_answer.excerpt:
Help us test desktop history syncing! Call for Testing
Hello, all! Some of you are aware that we’ve been working on a pretty cool device-independent backup format, and now we’re looking to test our first use-case: syncing your message history with a newly-linked device! You heard that right – your newly-linked devices will finally have all of your message history I think this is something we’ve all wanted for a while, so it’s really cool to finally build it. But building something like this is very tricky, and testing it tends to uncover lot…
